in a situation like
this, when it's flexible,

1108.02.text:
I could have the height
whatever I want it to be,

1109.94.text: it's not a bad idea to do it.

1111.82.text: So let's just see what it gives us.

1113.58.text:
We know that the total
width of this cabinet,

1116.88.text: basically using the top because it's going

1119.02.text:
to extend a little bit
further than the case itself,

1121.47.text:
so 43 and 1/4 inches
wide is where we're at.

1124.62.text: So I'm going to take 43 and 1/4

1127.40.text:
and in this case I'm
going to divide by 1.618

1130.25.text: because the side to side dimension

1134.11.text:
I don't want it to be
taller than it is wide.

1136.50.text: So I'm going to divide by 1.618

1138.96.text: and the number I get is 26 and 3/4

1144.05.text:
and that's total height from
the top to the very bottom.

1147.62.text: Now the top and bottom actual pieces

1150.42.text: are going to be 1 and a 1/2 inches thick

1152.53.text:
so if I take 26 and 3/4
and I subtract 3 inches,

1157.30.text: because each one is 1 and a half inches,

1159.28.text: that leaves me with 23 and 3/4 of an inch

1164.33.text:
Well, that's fine because
I really only need 23.

1168.13.text: So if I get 3/4 of an inch more

1169.82.text:
and I hit that Golden
Ratio, why the heck not?

1172.74.text: So that's exactly what we're going to do.

1174.88.text: And now really, the only thing left to do

1176.50.text:
is gather the materials
and start making our cuts.

1179.03.text: And we'll do that next time.

like rubber bands. What?

1195.06.text:
Smack it like you're mad
at me and it's my face.
